text: what did talk about in the state of
union will demonstrate that we're taking
steps to put our fiscal house in order
the planned announcement of a three-year
spending freeze on many domestic
programs hasn't made either side too
happy it's you're talking about trying
to cut 250 billion dollars out of the
budget first I have to tell you it
sounds completely completely insane if
my two daughters when they're in college
should come home and said at the end of
their freshman year I charge fifty
thousand dollars on my credit card this
year but you know I'm going to freeze
that level for the next three years I
don't know that I've been very impressed
it's a move to the middle and a way for
the president to get some applause from
both sides of the aisle during
Wednesday's state of the union address
some of the things we propose are things
that actually should get some strong
bipartisan support it only affects a
small portion of the budget is certainly
not going to solve the problem much more
has to be done as the White House is
acknowledged but the question is whether
it will be perceived as a public
relations move in the wake of the
massachusetts election or if it can
foster real bipartisan support just a
three year spending freeze frankly won't
do it although I think it's good to do
the president has borrowed an approach
from senator evan bayh a fiscally
conservative Democrat who has long
pushed for balanced budgets there's real
momentum people are finally starting to
get it last year he voted against the
Democratic budget I've been a fiscal
conservative throughout my career Chris
it's nothing personal to the president
it was after repeated meetings on the
subject including on Air Force One he
called me up to his personal office he
wanted to talk about the deficit the
budget both senator by and fiscally
conservative House members known as blue
dogs have been hesitant about spending
levels but got promises from the
president and a meeting a year ago that
he seems to be keeping today's meeting
was the meeting that the president made
verbal commitments we've got to start
putting some date certain on when we
start tightening down these things
with a viable path forward for health
care reform unclear it's the budget
that's taking center stage it only
requires 50 votes to pass and the
president wants to make deficit
reduction a big part of his second year
agenda today I'm pledging to cut the
deficit we inherited by half by the end
of my first term in office an example of
that commitment was when he summoned the
influential house budget committee
chairman John Spratt to a one-on-one
meeting in the Oval Office after rumors
circulated that the congressman would
retire he weighed in and said I need you
on the team we've got big budget issues
coming up and I hope you decide to carry
on mr. spread is still on the team and
how he and other members of Congress
respond to the idea will indicate
whether the president can accomplish a
key second year goal my sense is that he
is sincere about this he knows it's a
problem he's faced with a very difficult
situation having inherited a recession
which required one response but then a
long-term challenge that requires a
diagonally opposite response and we've
got a pivot and deal with the long-term
debt threat that sounds contradictory
unfortunately economics is often
contradictory
